Line 60: Line 60:
Nearly all recent BIOS implementations can optionally execute a setup program interfacing the [[nonvolatile BIOS memory]] (CMOS). This memory holds user-customizable configuration data ([[password]]s, [[time]], [[calendar date|date]], [[hard drive]] details, etc.) accessed by BIOS code. The [[80x86]] source code for early PC and AT BIOS was included with the "IBM Personal Computer Technical Reference Manual".<ref>This is how the book refers to itself on page i (first edition, August 1981). The actual title is merely <u>Technical Reference</u>, but both the slipcase cover and binder include the phrase "''Personal Computer Hardware Reference Library''" to separate it from other IBM "Technical Reference" works; e.g., those of the PC's ''Programming Family''. This particular ''Hardware Reference'' may also be cited as IBM Part Number <code>6025008</code> in which the listing of the BIOS code in small typeset fills 79 pages of Appendix A.</ref>
Nearly all recent BIOS implementations can optionally execute a setup program interfacing the [[nonvolatile BIOS memory]] (CMOS). This memory holds user-customizable configuration data ([[password]]s, [[time]], [[calendar date|date]], [[hard drive]] details, etc.) accessed by BIOS code. The [[80x86]] source code for early PC and AT BIOS was included with the "IBM Personal Computer Technical Reference Manual".<ref>This is how the book refers to itself on page i (first edition, August 1981). The actual title is merely <u>Technical Reference</u>, but both the slipcase cover and binder include the phrase "''Personal Computer Hardware Reference Library''" to separate it from other IBM "Technical Reference" works; e.g., those of the PC's ''Programming Family''. This particular ''Hardware Reference'' may also be cited as IBM Part Number <code>6025008</code> in which the listing of the BIOS code in small typeset fills 79 pages of Appendix A.</ref>
â
In most modern BIOS implementations, users select where the BIOS obtains its boot image: [[Compact Disc|CD]], [[hard disk]], [[floppy disk]], [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] device or via a networked connection. This is particularly useful for installing [[operating system]]s or booting to a [[LiveCD]] or [[flash drive|flash keydrive]], and for selecting the order of testing for the [[Presence information|presence]] of bootable media.
+
In most modern BIOS implementations, users select where the BIOS obtains its boot image: [[Compact Disc|CD]], [[hard disk]], [[floppy disk]], [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] device or via a networked connection. This is particularly useful for installing [[operating system]]s or booting to a [[Live CD]] or [[flash drive|flash keydrive]], and for selecting the order of testing for the [[Presence information|presence]] of bootable media.
Some BIOSes allow the user to select the operating system to load (e.g. load another OS from the second hard disk), though this is more often handled by a second-stage [[boot loader]].
Some BIOSes allow the user to select the operating system to load (e.g. load another OS from the second hard disk), though this is more often handled by a second-stage [[boot loader]].
